title: How to Bake Black Bat Cupcakes

steps.headline: Line two 12 capacity (standard) muffin pans with cupcake papers.
Intermix the flours in a small bowl.
Soften the butter in a larger bowl until it is smooth.
steps.description: Add the sugar slowly and purée until it is frothy, for about three minutes. Add the eggs, one at a time, whipping well after each supplement.

steps.headline: Insert the dry ingredients in three parts, mixing with the milk and vanilla.
steps.description: With each addition, beat until the ingredients are mixed well in.

steps.headline: Ladle the batter carefully into the cupcake liners, filling them about 3/4 full.
Let the mix bake for 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Remove from oven and let it cool before frosting.

steps.headline: Place the butter in a large mixing bowl for the frosting part.
steps.description: Add the sugar and then the milk and vanilla. On the medium speed of an electric mixer, purée the mix until smooth and creamy, about 3 to 5 minutes. Divide the frosting in half. Add a few drops of orange food coloring to one half and black frosting to the other (if you wish) and blend well.

steps.headline: Frost the cupcakes when entirely cooled down.
steps.description: The frosting looks best if you use half and half––one side of the cupcake orange frosting, the other side black. Frost in this manner, or simply frost with a single color if that is easiest. Decorate with black and orange sprinkles. This step is optional. Make black fondant bats. To make, cut out a small template of a bat design using thin card. Roll out the fondant and cut around the shape 24 times. Alternatively, use a small cookie cutter in the shape of a bat. Place the black fondant bats onto the cupcakes. They can either sit flat or you can poke them in one end and make them stand up.

steps.headline: Arrange the black bat cupcakes on a stand for display.
steps.description: A few bat toys can be added to the display for more effect.

text: Preheat oven to 350ºF or 180ºC.  Line two 12 capacity (standard) muffin pans with cupcake papers.  Intermix the flours in a small bowl. Set aside. Soften the butter in a larger bowl until it is smooth. Add the sugar slowly and purée until it is frothy, for about three minutes. Add the eggs, one at a time, whipping well after each supplement. Insert the dry ingredients in three parts, mixing with the milk and vanilla. With each addition, beat until the ingredients are mixed well in. Ladle the batter carefully into the cupcake liners, filling them about 3/4 full.  Let the mix bake for 20 to 25 minutes. Remove from oven and let it cool before frosting. Place the butter in a large mixing bowl for the frosting part. Add the sugar and then the milk and vanilla. On the medium speed of an electric mixer, purée the mix until smooth and creamy, about 3 to 5 minutes. Divide the frosting in half. Add a few drops of orange food coloring to one half and black frosting to the other (if you wish) and blend well. Frost the cupcakes when entirely cooled down. The frosting looks best if you use half and half––one side of the cupcake orange frosting, the other side black. Frost in this manner, or simply frost with a single color if that is easiest. Decorate with black and orange sprinkles. This step is optional. Make black fondant bats. To make, cut out a small template of a bat design using thin card. Roll out the fondant and cut around the shape 24 times. Alternatively, use a small cookie cutter in the shape of a bat. Place the black fondant bats onto the cupcakes. They can either sit flat or you can poke them in one end and make them stand up. Arrange the black bat cupcakes on a stand for display. A few bat toys can be added to the display for more effect. Finished.
